question: A local government intends to implement a primary prevention program against neurological diseases in the area. What is the measure that is most appropriate as a primary prevention in the community?

A 40-year-old man was bitten by a snake while working in his field. He was brought to the hospital within 30 minutes after the bite. He was anxious, and the healthcare provider noted his heart rate was 110 beats per minute, shallow breathing, and pinpoint pupils. He was immediately admitted to the ICU, and the hospital was planning the next step for him. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate management in this scenario?

answers.option: Apply ice pack to bite area
Make an incision at the bite site to let the venom out
Keep the affected limb immbolized at the heart level
Apply a torniquet above the bite site
Elevate the affected limb above heart leve

question: A lecturer was conducting a research study "to find out the associated risk factors of stomach cancer in Karachi city." He had limited budget and time to complete his study on stomach cancer, which is a rare disease in Pakistan. The following epidemiological study design is appropriate for his study objectives:

A professor was studying "the effect of high dose vitamin D on 5-year survival of stomach cancer." She identified 100 stomach cancer patients and then randomized 50 above patients to vitamin D and the other 50 to the placebo through coin toss. The above statement refers to one of the following study designs:

A student collected data from his residential colony about the nutritional habits of teenage children during the period of January to December 2023. The above statement refers to one of the following study designs:
A researcher wants to compare the mean Hemoglobin levels of male and female students. Which of the following statistical tests is appropriate to apply?

Stroke is a leading cause of disability and mortality worldwide, and reducing modifiable risk factors is crucial in high-risk populations. Which of the following is the most important modifiable risk factor for preventing stroke in high-risk populations?
A researcher wants to determine if there is an association between physical activity and depression. Which statistical test is most appropriate to analyze the association between these two variables?

A study was conducted to investigate whether a specific dietary supplement can reduce the risk of developing osteoarthritis. Participants are randomly assigned to receive either the supplement or a placebo, and their joint health is monitored after six months. Which epidemiological study design would be suitable for this research?
A lecturer wants to compare the mean body mass index of smokers, ex-smokers, and current smokers. She should choose the following statistical test for the above task:
A group of students want to compare the proportion of smokers among diabetics, pre-diabetics, and non-diabetics individuals. They should choose the following statistical test for the above task:

A survey of 100 men and 100 women revealed that 15 of the men and 36 of the women were overweight. Chi square test of significance was applied to find an association at Alpha = 0.05. Which one of the following options contains the correct decision if the calculated value for Chi square is greater than the Chi critical?

answers.option: Fail to accept the alternate hypothesis

question: A case-control study was conducted to find the association of sudden weight loss with gallbladder stones. The calculated odds ratio was 2.05. Which one of the following interpretations is the most appropriate?

When entering data into SPSS, it is important to consider the types of variables being used in the dataset. Which of the following variable types is most appropriate for categorical data such as gender or ethnicity?

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the ER with complaints of symmetric weakness in lower limbs, progressing to involve the trunk in 3 days. On examination, the plantar reflexes are down-going, and tone and reflexes are decreased in both lower limbs. What is the most appropriate investigation that you will suggest?

An 8-year-old child is brought to the ER with complaints of progressive weakness in lower limbs for 5 days and now involving the trunk with respiratory difficulty. On examination of lower limbs, reflexes are absent, power is reduced to 2/5 in both the lower limbs. CSF analysis shows increased protein. What is the most appropriate management in this child?

A 3-year-old child with no medical history was brought into the emergency department with a 1-day history of seizures and altered mental status. A head CT was obtained that reported an intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The patient was then stabilized and taken for a diagnostic angiogram, which was suggestive of an arteriovenous malformation (AVM). What will be your most appropriate next step for management?

answers.option: Give immediate bolus for surgical intervention

question: A 34-year-old male presents with vomiting preceded by an occipital headache of acute onset. On examination, he is conscious, alert, has photophobia, and positive neck stiffness. CT head is reported as normal. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman presents with pain in her right hand and forearm, which has been worsening over the past few weeks. There is no history of trauma. The pain is concentrated around the thumb and index finger and is often worse at night. Shaking her hand seems to provide some relief. On examination, there is weakness of the abductor pollicis brevis and reduced sensation to fine touch at the index finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old child presented to OPD with history of diarrhea for about 3 days and weakness on right side of body since morning. On examination HR 120b/min, RR 28/min, O2 96%, BP 90/64 mmHg. He is awake and follows commands. On examination left leg power 5/5, right arm power 3/5, right leg power 2/5, reflexes are brisk on right side. What will be the investigation of choice for his management?

A 4-year-old boy presented with weakness of left upper limb upon awakening. Past history was insignificant. On examination GCS was 15/15, cranial nerve intact, sensory system intact. Bulk normal in all 4 limbs. Tone and reflexes were normal in all the limbs except left upper limb where these were reduced. The most likely possibility for this presentation is:

A 34-year-old lady, with type 1 diabetes, presents to OPD with episodic headaches for the last 3 years, which are unilateral, throbbing in nature, associated with nausea and vomiting, phono-photophobia, occurring twice a week for last one month. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is a brainstem reflex that must be checked in a comatose patient?
Which of the following develop in the brain of Alzheimer’s patients and may cause the disease?

A 25-year-old male was seen in the emergency room with a left-sided throbbing headache, nausea, left-sided ptosis, and lacrimation. He has been having these attacks daily for the last 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old female presents to the ER with sudden severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, she has a GCS of 15/15, severe neck rigidity, ptosis on the right side, and dilated right pupil. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presents with three episodes of visual loss. She has recently developed an ataxic gait and often drops objects from her grip. On examination, her speech is slurred, and there is evidence of dysdiadochokinesia. A fundoscopy was performed and showed a pale optic disc. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man sustained a serious head injury in a road traffic collision. Two weeks later, he was still unarousable, failing to respond to stimuli, with no sleep-wake cycles or any voluntary actions. What is the most accurate description of this disorder?

A 22-year-old was hit by a car and had a head impact 4 hours ago. Following the incident, he developed vomiting and decreased consciousness. In the ER, he had one episode of tonic-clonic seizure. Examination showed a right eye bruise and a GCS of 10/15. Which is the most important diagnostic investigation?
What is the primary goal of treatment for muscular dystrophy?

answers.option: To manage symptoms and improve quality of life
To reduce the progression of disease

question: Which diagnostic tool is considered the gold standard for diagnosing myelopathy?
Which of the following is the most common site for hemorrhagic stroke:
What is the duration of a transient ischemic attack (TIA)?
Parkinsonism includes a combination of the following:
What is the investigation of choice for Parkinson's Disease:
Which of the following is the most common symptom of Multiple Sclerosis?

A patient came to the ER with a complaint of severe sudden onset headache associated with vomiting, according to him he has never had such kind of headache in the past. Which radiological examination would you advise as it is faster, easy to interpret, and has no contraindication for any foreign body?
MRI Brain is the best radiological modality for selected pathologies, which of the following best represents the set of diseases in which MRI scan is the gold standard?

answers.option: Brain tumor, metastasis, Dural venous sinus thrombosis

question: After recovering from a severe head injury, a patient is living with permanent disability and unable to join his previous social activities but can live an independent life. What is his Glasgow outcome score?
Which of the following disease processes usually doesn't need surgical intervention after trauma primarily until and unless intracranial pressure is not managed by conservative treatment?

A patient comes to the ER after a head injury. His GCS is 10/15. You suspect raised intracranial pressure as he is hypertensive, tachypneic, and his heart rate is reduced. What is this clinical presentation known as?
In principle, the pressure is distributed evenly throughout the cranial cavity, and the sum of all intracranial volumes is always constant because of which of the following reasons:

answers.option: The cavity is elastic and open
The cavity is inelastic and closed
The cavity is inelastic and open
The cavity is elastic and close

question: The smallest physiological motion unit of the spine to exhibit biomechanical characteristics similar to those of the entire spine is called?
In the final stages of disc degeneration, what is the likely radiological finding?

answers.option: Disc has high intensity in the central part of the disc and low intensity in the peripheral part of the disc
Disc has low signal intensity centrally and blurring of distinction between nucleus and annulus
Homogenous low signal with no distinction between nucleus and annulus
Disc has central horizontal line of low-signal intensity
Disc has uniformly high signal on T2

question: Which of the following antidepressant drugs have an effect on serotonin reuptake?
Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with which one of the following may induce a central serotonin syndrome?

A 68-year-old post-menopausal woman who is suffering from major depression. Her medical history indicates that she had an inadequate clinical benefit from previous trials of fluoxetine and imipramine. After discussion, you decide that she should start a trial with an SNRI after tapering her dose of fluoxetine. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?

A 32-year-old woman presents with a right distal radius fracture. She requests a regional anesthetic at the fracture site to avoid postoperative pain. She states she is allergic to both procaine and tetracaine, which cause swelling at her dentist’s office. Which local anesthetic is appropriate for use in this patient?
Which of the following can act as antagonists at benzodiazepine receptors?

71 years old male came to neurology OPD, with presenting symptoms of alterations in mental status, fever & headache. MRI shows inflammation in the temporal lobe. Which of the following organisms may show inflammatory infiltrates & Cowdry Type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies, and found in neurons and glia?

A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed as a case of Parkinson’s disease in the neurology outpatient department. The neurophysician suggested him levodopa for his disease management. Which of the following statements is true about the mechanism of action of levodopa?

answers.option: Levodopa is metabolized by acetylcholinesterase in brain
Levodopa is hydroxylated into the chemical compound in brain
Levodopa is directly converted into dopamine in periphery
Levodopa is decarboxylated into dopamine in brain

question: Regarding the drugs used for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease, which of the following statements is most accurate?

answers.option: Selegiline is a selective COMT inhibitor (catechol-O-methyl transferase inhibitor)
Dopamine receptor agonists should never be used in Parkisons before a trial of levodopa
Beneficial effects of Antimuscarinic drugs in Parkinson’s disease to relieve bradykinesia
Levodopa causes mydriasis and and may precipitate an acute attack of glaucoma

question: A patient suffering from a seizure disorder is diagnosed by EEG to be suffering from a type of generalized seizure that produces a neuronal bursting activity pattern. T-type calcium channels are known to cause this abnormal activation by increasing the synchronization of thalamocortical neurons, necessary for staying awake. This abnormal bursting pattern results in a state of unconsciousness or absence of seizures. Which of the following drugs is the most effective for this particular seizure disorder because it selectively blocks the channel subtype responsible for causing it?
Which of the following is a troublesome adverse effect of levodopa when used for Parkinson’s disease?

A male patient reported in the psychiatric clinic for his psychiatric problem. He was prescribed lithium for his mental issue. Which of the following statements is most accurate about the clinical indication of lithium?
Which of the following drugs shall be preferred in the treatment of acute opioid poisoning?
A 51-year-old woman with symptoms of major depression also has angle-closure glaucoma. Which of the following antidepressants should be avoided in this patient?

A 65-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of pain in the lower abdomen and not having passed urine for 16 hours. The bladder was found to be full. His son informed that he was depressed for the last two years and only the day before a doctor had given him some medicine. Which of the following drugs is he most likely to have received?

A Grade 1 teacher notices that one of her students, a 7-year-old girl, has been having episodes of sudden blanking out and staring vacantly in class. During these episodes, the girl does not respond to her name and seems to lose focus but recovers immediately afterward. When examined by a neurologist, the young girl’s EEG shows a 3-second spike-wave pattern. The neurologist diagnoses her with absence seizures. What would be a drug of first choice for treating this patient’s seizure disorder?

A 78-year-old man with a long history of seizure disorder controlled with phenytoin presents to his dentist for routine follow-up. Which of the following findings must the dentist be concerned about and evaluate for?

A 35-year-old woman is having several severe migraines per month. The migraines are disabling and not relieved by low doses of triptan therapy. Which is most appropriate for prophylaxis to reduce the frequency of her migraines?

A 29-year-old woman complains of migraine headaches associated with early onset of vomiting. Currently, she uses ibuprofen as needed for her migraines, but it is not very effective. Which of the following drugs would be ideal for this patient?

A 20-year-old male patient scheduled for hernia surgery was anesthetized with halothane and nitrous oxide; tubocurarine was provided for skeletal muscle relaxation. The patient rapidly developed tachycardia and became hypertensive. Generalized skeletal muscle rigidity was accompanied by marked hyperthermia. The patient should be treated immediately with:

A 35-year-old man presents with appendicitis and requires a surgical intervention. He has a family history of malignant hyperthermia. Which anesthetic agent is most appropriate to use in this patient?

A child requires multiple minor surgical procedures involving the nasopharynx. Which drug has high surface local anesthetic activity and intrinsic vasoconstrictor actions that reduce bleeding in mucous membranes?

A 23-year-old man has a pheochromocytoma, blood pressure of 190/120 mm Hg. His catecholamines are elevated, and he has a well-defined abdominal tumor on MRI. He has been scheduled for surgery. Which one of the following agents should be avoided in the anesthesia protocol?

An infant, who presents complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, bulging fontanelle, fever & neck stiffness. The introduction of vaccination against which of the following has markedly reduced the incidence of acute pyogenic meningitis in the developed world, particularly among infants, who used to be at high risk?

65 years old male came to neurology OPD, he has complaints of deficits in memory, visuospatial orientation, judgment, personality, and language. Which of the following are the major microscopic abnormalities of Alzheimer’s disease?

answers.option: Cowdry Type A Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

question: A 65-year-old male with a stroke presented to Rehabilitation OPD having left-side hemiplegia and spastic gait. Which of the following orthosis is most commonly used to improve gait of patients with stroke having spastic gait?
A person with Parkinson’s Disease presented at Rehabilitation Medicine OPD for management. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the rehabilitation management of Parkinson's disease?

answers.option: Increased weighted utensils and adaptive equipment will improve ADLs.
There are no rehabilitation management options available for Parkinson’s disease.
Auditory and visual queuing increase risk of fall
Psychologist will give therapy to improve Activity of daily living ADLs
Exercise is harmful and increase the progress of disease

question: A 30-year-old man visited a psychiatric OPD with episodic illness for the last 5 years. He is on treatment with mood stabilizers and antipsychotics. What could be the possible diagnosis?

An 18-year-old girl presents with complaints of frequent, involuntary motor acts of clapping and head-shaking that have significantly disrupted her daily life for 2-3 months. She also reports having an urge to perform these behaviors to relieve tension and finds temporary relief after doing so. There is no history of substance abuse, and her neurological examination is unremarkable. Which of the following findings would most likely support a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) over a neurological disorder?

answers.option: Impaired functioning and quality of life
Uncontrollable urge to perform motor tasks
Childhood history of fever and excessive motor activity
Repetitive behaviors performed to reduce anxiety

question: A 16-year-old girl was brought to the emergency with a brief history of low mood, poor sleep, irritability, and suicidal thoughts. There was no history of substance abuse and no history of suicidal attempts in the past. Her parents reported that she was upset about her poor board results. What is the most likely antidepressant safe in that girl?

An 18-month-old unvaccinated child presented with the inability to stand and bear weight on the left foot. On examination, the child was conscious, febrile, and unable to stand or walk with decreased tone, power, and reflexes in the left lower limb. Plantars were going down. A junior resident on duty ordered an MRI of the brain with contrast. Keeping the most likely diagnosis in mind, which investigation needs to be done on priority?

A 7-year-old vaccinated girl presented with progressive asymmetrical weakness of lower limbs over a short period. Both limbs were flaccid, with no cranial nerve involvement. Tone and power in the lower limbs were decreased to 2/5, and reflexes were diminished. Sensory examination was normal, as were the upper limbs. The child was conscious and cooperative. What do these clinical findings most likely describe?

A 64-year-old male presented with sudden-onset high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. On examination, he had positive Brudzinski's sign and photophobia. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showed elevated white blood cell count with predominantly neutrophils, low glucose, and elevated protein. What should be the empirical treatment?

A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis presented with a severe headache, fever, and right-sided weakness. He also had papilledema on examination. CT scan of the brain revealed a ring-enhancing lesion in the left frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

answers.option: Start empirical antibiotics with surgical consultation
Perform lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid analysis

question: Which of the intracerebellar nuclei is not present in the white matter of the cerebellar hemisphere?
Which of the following areas do cortical branches of the anterior cerebral artery supply?
Which of the following is the only cranial nerve arising from the posterior surface of the brain?
A brain-dead patient will have a GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of?
When general anesthesia is being administered to a patient, which of the following is the main consideration given to?

A 55-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of highly variable drooping of both upper eyelids and transient double vision, especially in the evening. On examination, she has striking bilateral fatigable ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze, with easily visible, and fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness of the neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A lecturer was conducting a research study "to find out the associated risk factors of stomach cancer in Karachi city." He had a limited budget and time to complete this study on stomach cancer which is a rare disease in Pakistan. Which of the following epidemiologic study designs are useful in this scenario?

A case-control study was conducted to find the association between sudden weight loss with gallbladder stones. The calculated odds ratio was 2.05. Which one of the following interpretations is the most appropriate?
Which of the following is the most common site involved in herpetic encephalitis?

A 25-year-old woman presented with a history of intermittent dysphagia. She was unable to hang out more than four items of washed clothing to dry without resting and had experienced breathlessness over the past 6 months. On examination, she had neck flexor weakness and weak proximal arm muscles. Her sensory examination and tendon reflexes were normal. His lab investigations reveal: Serum-corrected calcium: Normal, Serum phosphate: Normal, Serum creatine kinase: Mildly elevated, Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and FT4: Normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Haloperidol is not a suitable treatment option for which of the following conditions?
Which SSRI is the least likely to inhibit CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 resulting in fewer drug interactions?

A 32-year-old woman presents for a right distal radius fracture. She requests regional anesthesia to help with her pain postoperatively. She reports that as a child, she had an allergic reaction to Novocain (procaine) at the dentist’s office. Which local anesthetic is appropriate for use in this patient?

A patient with a spinal cord injury at C6 is admitted to the ward and suddenly complains of severe headache, flushing, dizziness, and disorientation. Her Foley catheter was clogged. Her BP was 160/100 mmHg. What is your diagnosis?

A 21-year-old male is brought to the OPD by his father with complaints of social isolation, speaking to himself, and claiming that there are cameras in his room through which aliens spy on him, for the past 7 months. At times, he starts trembling and crying and says, "They are going to kill me," whereas sometimes he starts laughing out loud. He refuses to eat anything cooked at home, claiming it is poisoned. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman with diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia presented with muscle pain and weakness in her proximal arms and legs for three weeks. She has been taking treatment for her comorbid conditions for the past two to three months. Examination showed 4/5 power in proximal muscles. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated creatine kinase levels. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
Which part of the twelfth cranial nerve receives fibers only from the contralateral cerebral cortex?

answers.option: The part supplying the styloglossus muscle
The part supplying the hyoglossus muscle
The part supplying the palatoglossus muscle
The part supplying the intrinsic muscles of the tongue
The part supplying the genioglossus muscle

question: In which of the following conditions general anesthesia cannot be given?

answers.option: Any patient can be given general anesthesia

question: A 30-year-old software engineer presents with complaints of intense worrying about trivial issues that interfere with his performance for 1 month. He has recently started a new job at a fast-paced tech company. He has felt increasingly stressed due to long work hours and high-performance expectations. He finds himself thinking about work even during his time off, which occasionally makes it difficult to fall asleep. He also has occasional heart palpitations, sweating, and a sense of dread that he struggles to control. Which of the following best distinguishes this patient’s experience as an anxiety disorder rather than a normal state of stress?

answers.option: Persistent, intense worry that disrupts his functioning
Preoccupation with work tasks outside of work hours
Increased stress due to high expectations at a new job

question: A 61 years old male came to the emergency, with complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, clouding of consciousness, and neck stiffness. A spinal tap yields cloudy or frankly purulent CSF, with as many as 90,000 neutrophils per cubic millimeter, an increased protein concentration, and markedly reduced glucose content. Bacteria may be seen on a smear or may be cultured. Which of the following microorganisms cause Acute Pyogenic (Bacterial) Meningitis in older adults?

A college student is brought to the emergency department by friends. The physician is informed that the student had taken a drug and then "went crazy." The patient is agitated and delirious. Several persons are required to hold him down. His skin is warm and sweaty, and his pupils are dilated. Bowel sounds are normal. Signs and symptoms include tachycardia, marked hypertension, hyperthermia, increased muscle tone, and both horizontal and vertical nystagmus. The most likely cause of these symptoms is intoxication from?

A 25-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of highly variable drooping of both upper eyelids, transient double vision, especially in the evening, and “fatigue.” On examination, she has striking bilateral fatigable ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze with easily visible fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness of neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old male has a progressive weakness for the last 2 years. He says that weakness started in his left upper limb, then involved his right lower limb, followed by his left lower limb and then his right upper limb. He had no vision problems or bowel and bladder dysfunction. On examination, he has tongue fasciculations, weakness of all four limbs, fasciculations in limb muscles, brisk reflexes, and positive babinski sign. He does not have any sensory deficits. His NCS/EMG shows widespread denervation patterns. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with complaints of delayed motor milestones, difficulty in climbing stairs, and frequent falls. On examination, the child was walking with a protuberant abdomen and using his hands to push himself up from the floor. Which of the following findings are most likely to be present on examination?

answers.option: Spasticity and clonus in lower limbs
Distal muscle atrophy with normal reflexes

question: A 38-year-old man presented with complaints of progressive muscle weakness and difficulty lifting objects for 6 months. It was associated with significant weight loss, dry cough, and muscle pain. On examination, he had 3/5 power in proximal muscles with intact reflexes and normal sensation. Laboratory tests revealed an elevation in creatine kinase levels. Electromyography showed signs of irritable myopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presented with a history of multiple episodes of unconsciousness for the last few months. Each episode lasted for 2-3 minutes and she had no recall of events. The investigation didn't reveal any neurological deficit. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate?
There are four principal routes by which microbes enter the nervous system. Which of the following virus may be transported along the nervous system?
